meanings.def: to clean a room, surface, etc. using a broom (= a type of brush on a long handle)
examples: sweep (something) to sweep the floor
Chimneys should be swept regularly.
I don't have to sweep and mop every day.
sweep up Don't just stand around—grab a broom and sweep up.
sweep something + adj. The showroom had been emptied and swept clean.

meanings.def: to remove something from a surface using a brush, your hand, etc.
examples: She swept the crumbs into the wastebasket.
He swept the leaves up into a pile.
She swept the clothes onto the floor and invited him to sit down.

meanings.def: to move or push somebody/something suddenly and with a lot of force
examples: The little boat was swept out to sea.
Their tent was swept away in the storm.
She let herself be swept along by the crowd.

meanings.def: to move suddenly and/or with force over an area or in a particular direction
examples: + adv./prep. Rain swept in through the broken windows.
A fire swept through the store on Tuesday night.
sweep something Strong winds regularly sweep the islands.

meanings.def: to move quickly and/or smoothly, especially in a way that impresses or is intended to impress other people
examples: Without another word she swept out of the room.
Two police motorcycles swept through the village.
A pair of golden eagles swept across the sky.
She swept past the photographers without a glance.
(figurative) He swept into the lead with an almost perfect performance.

meanings.def: to move something, especially your hand or arm, quickly and smoothly in a particular direction
examples: He rushed to greet her, sweeping his arms wide.
She swept a hand through her hair.
The traveller swept a hand toward the endless expanse of water.

meanings.def: to suddenly affect somebody strongly
examples: A wave of tiredness swept over her.
Memories came sweeping back.

meanings.def: to spread quickly
examples: + adv./prep. Rumours of his resignation swept through the company.
sweep something the latest craze sweeping the nation

meanings.def: to move over an area, especially in order to look for something
examples: + adv./prep. His eyes swept around the room.
The car headlights swept across the front of the building.
sweep something Searchlights swept the sky.
She swept the crowd with her binoculars.

meanings.def: to move, or move something, over a surface, touching it lightly
examples: Her dress swept the ground as she walked.

meanings.def: to brush, comb, etc. your hair in a particular direction
examples: Her hair was swept back from her face.

meanings.def: to form a long, smooth curve
examples: The hotel gardens sweep down to the beach.

meanings.def: to win all the games in a series of games against another team or all the parts of a contest
examples: The Blue Jays have a chance to sweep the series.
New Jersey swept Detroit last season.

meanings.def: to win all the prizes, etc. in a competition
to make somebody fall suddenly and deeply in love with you
examples: She’s waiting for some hero to come and sweep her off her feet.

meanings.def: to win an election by a large number of votes; to make somebody win an election with a large number of votes
to win a contest easily
examples: Macron swept to victory in 2017.

meanings.def: to try to stop people from finding out about something wrong, illegal, embarrassing, etc. that has happened or that you have done
examples: An earlier report, implicating the government, had been conveniently swept under the carpet.

idioms.def: to win all the prizes, etc. in a competition
to make somebody fall suddenly and deeply in love with you
examples: She’s waiting for some hero to come and sweep her off her feet.

idioms.def: to win an election by a large number of votes; to make somebody win an election with a large number of votes

examples: Macron swept to victory in 2017.

idioms.def: to try to stop people from finding out about something wrong, illegal, embarrassing, etc. that has happened or that you have done
examples: An earlier report, implicating the government, had been conveniently swept under the carpet.

meanings.def: an act of cleaning a room, surface, etc. using a broom
examples: Give the room a good sweep.

meanings.def: a smooth curving movement
examples: He indicated the door with a sweep of his arm.
He dismissed his assistant with a grandiose sweep of his hand.
(figurative) Thousands of jobs were lost in one broad sweep.

meanings.def: a long, often curved, piece of road, river, coast, etc.
examples: the broad sweep of white cliffs around the bay
The house overlooks the great sweep of the St Lawrence River.
An elegant sweep of lawn led up to the house.

meanings.def: the range of an idea, a piece of writing, etc. that considers many different things
examples: Her book covers the long sweep of the country's history.
the broad cultural sweep of Flaubert's novel

meanings.def: a movement over an area, for example in order to search for something or attack something
examples: The rescue helicopter made another sweep over the bay.
Her eyes made a comprehensive sweep of the room.
We made a wide sweep south to the River Dee.

meanings.def: a person whose job is to clean the inside of chimneys
a sweepstake (= a type of betting in which the winner gets all the money bet by everyone else)
a series of games that a team wins against another team; the fact of winning all the parts of a contest
examples: a World Series sweep

meanings.def: a time when television companies examine their programmes to find out which ones are the most popular, especially in order to calculate advertising rates
examples: the May ratings sweeps

meanings.def: to remove all the people or things from an organization that are thought to be unnecessary or need changing
examples: The new manager made a clean sweep of the department.

meanings.def: to win all the prizes or parts of a game or competition; to win an election completely
examples: China made a clean sweep of the medals in the gymnastics events.
The opinion poll suggests a clean sweep for the Democrats.

idioms.def: to remove all the people or things from an organization that are thought to be unnecessary or need changing
examples: The new manager made a clean sweep of the department.
China made a clean sweep of the medals in the gymnastics events.
The opinion poll suggests a clean sweep for the Democrats.
